articles.headline: For Ukraine, Many Antiwar Activists in the U.S. Make an Exception
articles.snippet: Several reasons might explain the differing response, including the fact that no American troops have been committed to the fight.
articles.abstract: Several reasons might explain the differing response, including the fact that no American troops have been committed to the fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: On an August Sunday in Amherst, Mass., a small peace vigil was underway near the town center, extending a weekly tradition dating back to the 1970s.

articles.headline: Judge Rules in Favor of Montana Youths in a Landmark Climate Case
articles.snippet: The court found that young people have a constitutional right to a healthful environment and that the state must consider potential climate damage when approving projects.
articles.abstract: The court found that young people have a constitutional right to a healthful environment and that the state must consider potential climate damage when approving projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of young people in Montana won a landmark lawsuit on Monday when a judge ruled that the state’s failure to consider climate change when approving fossil fuel projects was unconstitutional.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Mike Baker

articles.headline: She Was Brazil’s Barbie. Now She’s Saying Sorry.
articles.snippet: Xuxa was once Brazil’s biggest TV star. Now many are wondering whether a thin, blond, white woman was the right idol for such a diverse country.
articles.abstract: Xuxa was once Brazil’s biggest TV star. Now many are wondering whether a thin, blond, white woman was the right idol for such a diverse country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of Brazilians grew up watching her on television. Her shows sold out Latin America’s biggest stadiums. She had hit movies and songs, her own dolls and her own amusement park.

articles.headline: China Suspends Report on Youth Unemployment, Which Was at a Record High
articles.snippet: The Chinese government said it would no longer release monthly data about unemployment in young people, which had risen each month this year and reached 21.3 percent.
articles.abstract: The Chinese government said it would no longer release monthly data about unemployment in young people, which had risen each month this year and reached 21.3 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Chinese government, facing an expected seventh consecutive monthly increase in youth unemployment, said Tuesday that it had instead suspended release of the information.

articles.headline: The Long, Lonely Wait for Justice for 17 Fallen U.S. Sailors
articles.snippet: Families of the sailors who were killed in the bombing of the U.S.S. Cole and survivors having been making the trek to the war court at Guantánamo Bay for pretrial hearings since 2011.
articles.abstract: Families of the sailors who were killed in the bombing of the U.S.S. Cole and survivors having been making the trek to the war court at Guantánamo Bay for pretrial hearings since 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the nearly 12 years since a prisoner was charged in the bombing of the U.S.S. Cole warship, eight parents of the 17 fallen American sailors have died waiting for a trial to begin.

articles.headline: With Racketeering Charges, Georgia Prosecutor Aims to ‘Tell the Whole Story’
articles.snippet: Prosecutors have found racketeering laws to be powerful tools in targeting not only foot soldiers in a criminal enterprise, but also high-level decision makers.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors have found racketeering laws to be powerful tools in targeting not only foot soldiers in a criminal enterprise, but also high-level decision makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than 50 years, prosecutors have relied on a powerful tool to take down people as varied as mafia capos, street gangs like the Crips and the Bloods and pharmaceutical executives accused of fueling the opioid crisis.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: How Fire Turned Lahaina Into a Death Trap
articles.snippet: When a historic coastal town in Hawaii was overrun by fire, many residents fled for their lives — but there was nowhere to go.
articles.abstract: When a historic coastal town in Hawaii was overrun by fire, many residents fled for their lives — but there was nowhere to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only three hours before she found herself huddled in the Pacific Ocean, a barrage of embers and ash hurtling above her, Chelsea Denton Fuqua was lounging in bed with a fan, a pristine blue sky outside the window of her home that lies half a mile from the Lahaina waterfront on the Hawaiian island of Maui.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Serge F. Kovaleski, Shawn Hubler and Riley Mellen

articles.headline: Report on Anti-Gay Slur Could Put Local News Site Out of Business
articles.snippet: When a north-central Wisconsin news site reported that a businessman had uttered a homophobic slur, he sued, claiming defamation. The legal bills are piling up.
articles.abstract: When a north-central Wisconsin news site reported that a businessman had uttered a homophobic slur, he sued, claiming defamation. The legal bills are piling up.
articles.lead_paragraph: The county board meeting in Wausau, Wis., on Aug. 12, 2021, got contentious fast. Nobody disputes that.
